Name: Mohammad Rajabi Seraji
Overview: I am a passionate UI/UX developer and love designing seamless user experiences. I'm also a mathematics enthusiast and love learning about new ideas in the field.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Summer of 2018 program. As I worked with react for quite some time, I was able to gather some source materials in order to teach a course about fundamentals of react. In this course I mainly focused on basic characteristics of the framework and introduced concepts such as Web Components, component relationships, event handling and syntax of react and also pointed to some basic Redux matters, as well. In every other session, the students were tasked to complete a code snippet like the one they saw in the previous session and could participate in the learning process by doing this activiy. In the end all of them were tasked to create a simple shopping app using the things they'd just learnt. The evaluation for this course is yet to be ready.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.course: Practical Front-end Design and Development using Vue and Nuxt.js
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Summer of 2017 Professional program. My co-worker, Pouya and I decided to make a workshop in order to teach the fundamentals of the newly arrived Nuxt framework, a framework which offers great flexibility and high performance results. The course required the students to have the basic knowledge of new JavaScript and was mostly an advanced one. During the course runtime, we introduced Vue and its basic syntax and code-style, along with a reactive way of thinking in Vue. We also introduced the basic concepts of Server-side rendering using Node.js servers to serve a hydrated code to the front-end and improve performance and SEO by all means. The students took part in an intensive Nuxt workshop at the end and learned the project structure and policies, made by the team behind it. We were both rated "Very Good" by the students at the final evaluation.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Faculty of Computer Engineering and IT of Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic)
Teaching.description: I was the main lecturer of Computer Programming lab in which the freshmen of our faculty learned how to program using C/C++. During the course runtime, I introduced the students to the new faculty, professors and also the way things work around our faculty. During the course, students worked in groups and did the programming tasks, together. I was ranked the second best lecturer of that semester by the students' rankings.

Teaching.title: TA
Teaching.description: I had three main tasks during this Teaching Assistantship period. First, I was in charge of coming up with a proper mid-term project for the students. Grading a fourth of all projects and homeworks was also one of my responsibilities. I, also created the student's second homework assignment.

Teaching.title: TA
Teaching.description: I was the head teaching assistant of the course. My responsibilities included teaching extra classes on practical subjects, making weekly challenges for the students, making the homework questions and also creating the mid-term and final projects. I was also responsible for managing the grading TAs, assigning homewroks to them and also collect and report their results to the professor.
Teaching.projectText: The repository for the homeworks and projects are available in the links below.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.course: Practical Front-end Design and Development using Vue and Nuxt.js
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Summer of 2017 Professional program. My co-worker, Pouya and I decided to make a workshop in order to teach the fundamentals of the newly arrived Nuxt framework, a framework which offers great flexibility and high performance results. The course required the students to have the basic knowledge of new JavaScript and was mostly an advanced one. During the course runtime, we introduced Vue and its basic syntax and code-style, along with a reactive way of thinking in Vue. We also introduced the basic concepts of Server-side rendering using Node.js servers to serve a hydrated code to the front-end and improve performance and SEO by all means. The students took part in an intensive Nuxt workshop at the end and learned the project structure and policies, made by the team behind it. We were both rated "Very Good" by the students at the final evaluation.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Spring program of 2017. In this course I put the main focus on team work and preparing to work as a front-end development team. My students were introduced to working with Git, individually and also as a team. Going forward I taught them about basics of HTML and CSS in a crash course style; this crash course was accompanied by a comprehensive excercise to ensure they're well used to the core concepts. The majority of the sessions, though, were dedicated to the JavaScript Concepts, classic JS vs new one, ES6 and ES7, build and deploy automation tools and bundlers. This course was a dense package of all the basic tools the students needed to go forward in web development area. I was rate "Excelent", again by my students in the final evaluation.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.course: An Introduction to Front-end Development in Vue 2
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Spring program of 2017. I carefully constructed a series of slides based on the documentations of the Vue and also made 4 sample code snippets for each session. During the course students used to learn about Singltons in web programming and were also introduced to the world of web components. The first session was an introduction into the basics of Vue and reactive thinking, along with a sample Todo app in vue. We were exploring componentization of a web page and website in second and third sessions. Finally the students were introduced to Stores in vue, which is implemented in Vuex and became aquainted with the concepts of Actions, Mutations and States. Our course work was put to test in final project, in which the students were tasked to create an interactive homepage for themselves using the introduced concepts. The students rated me "Excelent" in the final evaluations.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.course: Back-end Web Development Using PHP and Laravel
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Fall program. The program was mainly targeted freshmen and other new students of computer enigneering/science and was offered in five session (25 hours in total). I was the main lecturer of the course, accompanied by an assistant to help the students keep up with the workshop sessions. During the course, students learned about server-side scripting with PHP; their basic knowledge of PHP was then used as a way to introduce them to Laravel, an advanced PHP framework for web artisans. My task was to gather enough educational material in form of slides, workshops and projects to keep the atmosphere live and engaging. Student evalutaions from the course was gathered by the S.S.C and it was rated "Mostly Positive".The syllabus of the course alongside more information about the sessions are available in the course links.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.course: Basics of Web Developement (How to Become a Web Developer)
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Summer program. This program was quite identical to the one that I presented in the spring. Although, there was a little change in my presentation method. In the courses, prior to this one, I used slide presentations alongside practical coding. During this course I focused more on the practical side in order to help the students leaning into the conecepts. Course work is available in the Github repo. You can also find the course syllabus in the links below.

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Spring program. The program was mainly targeted freshmen and other new students of computer enigneering/science and was offered in five session (25 hours in total). In this course, I concentrated on the basic aspects of web development and its basic technologies, namely HTML 5, CSS and basic JavaScript. This course assumes that the learner has close to no prior experience in web design and focuses on introducing the students to the world of web development. I dedicated the first two sessions of the course to a basic introduction and history of web, as well as baby steps towards programming in that world. The other sessions were dedicated to workshops in which the students coded in real-time and compared the results to each other. more information is available in the links below.

Teaching.title: TA
Teaching.prof: Dr. Hamid R. Zarandi - Associate Professor

Teaching.title: LECT
Teaching.location: Student Scientific Chapter of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Teaching.course: Basics of Web Design and Development
Teaching.description: The course was offered as a part of Student Scientific Chapter's Summer program of 2015. This was my first teaching experience other than my previous teaching assistantships. I used the knowledge of web development, I learned from my summer internships in order to teach the basic alphabet of web development to the students. This course, mainly consisted of HTML 5, CSS 3 and vanilla JS introduction to the students. It served me well, as it was my initial experience of teaching to people other than my university students. In the end, I was ranked "Fairly Good" by the students.

Working.title: Snappfood co.
Working.firstJobDesc: My responsinilities include choosing a modern JS framework for the main web-app of Snappfood, the first online food ordering system in Iran. I researched for a month and benchmarked Vue, React, Preact and Angular in different situations; as a result, my team and I concluded that we'd go with React, a reliable framework with rich community and support. I was in charge of managing my team, creating tasks for the team members, choosing a comprehensive project structure and creating a fine-tuned boileplate that is reusable in the company's other products. We developed a fully fleshed Progressive Web App (PWA) complying with the latest Google standards from ground up. This web app is now ready for mobile devices and is avilable at the link below. We worked with SCRUM method and I was my teams sprint manager. Snappfood was a great environment for me to flourish and develop a fast and lite web-app.

Working.title: Fandogh co.
Working.firstJobDesc: I was in charge of a team of five junior developers in order to develop the latest corporation products. The two main product we worked on was "Amirkabir University of Technology's Diner Web App" and "Chavosh: Amirkabir University of Technology's Social Media PWA". We were using the latest Front-end technologies of Vue and Nuxt and also contributing to the Nuxt community on a regular basis. My job was to maintain team stability, represent goals in terms of smaller tasks and assigning them to each team members and also managing weekly SCRUM sessions. For the back-end tech. we used Node.js's framework, Hapi that was changed in order to meet our project specifications. it's also notable to mention that by GitHub statistics of 2017, our organization ranks in the top 5 of our country. The diner project was halted due to some problems from the university contractors but "Chavosh" is live and kicking :D you can checkout for your self in the links below.  Be sure to also check it on mobile, it's a real treat for the sore eyes ;)

Working.title: AUT
Working.location: Office of Information, IT and Communications of Department of Education of Amirkabir University of Technology
Working.firstJobDesc: I worked alongside a team of talented web developers on the Amirkabir University Support System (Trouble Ticketing) which is currently available at https://support.aut.ac.ir. We worked for the office of Information and Technology of the university and under the supervision of Dr. Mehdi Dehghan. The full description of the project is available in the projects section.

Working.title: AUT
Working.titleDescription: Project Manager and Senior Web Developer
Working.location: Department of International Affairs of Amirkabir University of Technology
Working.firstJobDesc: I was working as the project manager to bring a new "Scholarship System Search Engine" to the university. I was responsible for creating the basic structure of the project, including our technology stack, the method of team-work and also the deadlines. I also worked as a front and back-end developer for this project. We used PHP's framework, Laravel and its templating engine in order to develop our backend. We also used JQuery and Bootstrap as the main Tech behind our front-end. The project started with great pace and was released on time. Right now, though, the website is down due to the universitiy's lack of maintenance and support. We also used Docker as the main means of deployment. You can checkout the project repository in the link below.

Working.title: AUT
Working.firstJobDesc: Arang IT is among the top corporations in Learning Management Systems and I learned programming with for iOS platform using Objective-C and also leanred the process of Android programming with Java in Android Studio. During this internship, I participated in making of a Learning Management System (LMS) and at the end also learned to code in basic PHP. This was done as a summer internship.

Executive.title: AUT
Executive.titleDescription: Head of Communications and Industrial Connections Department
Executive.location: Student Scientific Chapter (SSC) of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Executive.firstJobDesc: Student Scientific Chapter of our university is a place built by the students, for the students, but unlike Student Council (also known as Student Government), its goal is to create a fun and engaging environment for the students to engage in academic and scientific events. Our responsibilites included holding Talks, Panels, Innovation Fairs, Job Fairs, Scietific Contests, Educational Workshops and etc. The members of this organization were chosen by the direct vote of the faculty students each year. This term was my second round of activity as a member of SSC and my responsibility was to establish a meaningful relationship between SSC and IT comrporations that were interested in investing the events or funding scientific fairs. During my time as a member, I participated in holding of many events such as 16th International AUT ACM ICPC, 8th National Linux Festival and etc. You can see a long list of these events and my roles in each of them in the executive experience section.

links.title: Student Associations Office of Amirkabir University of Technology
Student Associations Office of Amirkabir University of Technology Alumni of Computer Engineering Faculty

Executive.title: AUT
Executive.titleDescription: Head of Innovations and Scientific Olympiads Department
Executive.location: Student Scientific Chapter (SSC) of Computer Engineering and IT Faculty of Amirkabir University of Technology
Executive.firstJobDesc: Student Scientific Chapter of our university is a place built by the students, for the students, but unlike Student Council (also known as Student Government), its goal is to create a fun and engaging environment for the students to engage in academic and scientific events. Our responsibilites included holding Talks, Panels, Innovation Fairs, Job Fairs, Scietific Contests, Educational Workshops and etc. The members of this organization were chosen by the direct vote of the faculty students each year. My role in this organization was to make sure that we have a proper connection with students and alumni who want to present their novel ideas to the industrial leaders of the field. I was also in charge of managing our olympiad teams, our robotic teams and making sure they have the proper funding and support for their work. One of my other responsibilities was to keep in touch with the outstanding alumni of our faculty and hold occasional(monthly) talks with them as the main speaker. You can see a vast list of events in which I contributed in the executive experience section.

Education.title: BSc.
Education.minor: Minor: Computer Architecture and Hardware Design

Research.title: Indoor Mapping and Tracking in Wi-Fi based Networks
Research.location: Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic)– A.U.T
Research.description: This is my thesis project and I've been working on it for the past year and a half. My main task in this project is to implement and benchmark the current Indoor mapping and Tracking technologies both on dedicated and general purpose hardware. Using the benchmark data I've come up with a new way that combines accoustic mapping and Wi-Fi fingerprinting to acquire a 2D map of an indoor environment and actively track the connected users in it. This is a hot topic in networking and has quite a large demand in the market.

Research.title: Quadrotor Simulation with LQR Estimation in MATLAB
Research.location: Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic)– A.U.T
Research.description: In this project we made a simulation of a Quadrotor in MATLAB using LQR feedback control technique. At last we had a visual simulation of a fully controlled quadrotor (with help of a little bit of SolidWorks model)

Research.title: Design a Simple Scheduler C0-design with Spartan FPGA and Microblaze Core
Research.location: Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic)– A.U.T

Research.title: FEC Code Optimization in Wireless Sensor Networks
Research.location: Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic)– A.U.T

skills.title: Node.js
skills.description: I learnt it about 4 years ago by self-study and have been working with it directly or indirectly(in React, Vue, Hapi, ...) ever since.

skills.title: JavaScript (ECMA 6)
skills.description: This new form of JavaScript is the one I've been constantly learning and pursing ever since I became aware of Node.js and I've been coding in this style for quite a long time.

skills.title: PHP
skills.description: This was the first back-end scripting language I learnt, back in the day. I must be honest, I don't really like it :D I used it a lot during my Laravel era, but right now, not su much. (or at all :D)

skills.title: Java (J2EE)
skills.description: The first OOP language I was taught in the university. I used it for some projects including my RTS game in the second semester and some other projects like implementing Network layers in Network I course.

skills.title: C/C++
skills.description: The very first programming language I learned. I used it for the whole first semseter and made a C to assembly comiler in it. I also used it a lot during my hardware development era, using it in 8086 programming, Arduino Programming and for a large portion of my Thesis project.

skills.title: VHDL
skills.description: I learned it in Logic Design course in my third semster and used it in my hardware projects that required low level designs (Comp. Arch., Logic and FPGA).

skills.title: 8086 Assembly
skills.description: I used it mostly during my Microprocessor course and Lab in order to develop programs for 8086 processors

skills.title: Objective C
skills.description: The first language I used to make iOS programs. I'm quite familiar with the older versions of it but haven't been working with it for 2 years, now.

skills.title: Swift
skills.description: This was the second lang. I leadrned to create iOS programs. It's really good and flexible but I haven't been working with it for 1.5 years now.

skills.title: Python
skills.description: I've been using it mostly for my thesis project and do not have a lot of experience in it. Although I'm developing my knowledge in it using many self-study courses.

skills.title: MATLAB
skills.description: I learned this for Liner Control Systems course and used it to develop a Quadrotor simulation as the final course project.

skills.title: Visual Studio Code
skills.description: I've known it for 2 years now, and I think it's one of the most flexible, fast and most stunning editor/IDE I've ever seen. The fact that it's been made using Electron fascinates me and the rich community support and extensions behind it are great for the development purposes. I've been using it non-stop and to develop almost anything since 2 years ago.

skills.title: Jetbrains IntelliJ
skills.description: Before I was introduced to VSCode I used it quite a lot. The code snippet and completion features of it were quite good and its debuggin feature made it an ideal tool for programmers, yet its lack of speed made me move to VScode, eventually.

skills.title: Webstorm IDE
skills.description: Refer to my descriptions about IntelliJ

skills.title: PHPStorm IDE
skills.description: Refer to my descriptions about IntelliJ.

skills.title: Eclipse
skills.description: I used it mostly to develop Java programs, I know it fairly well but haven't been using it for almost 3 years, now.

skills.title: Atmel Studio
skills.description: My main tool for developing 8086 and AVR Provessor programs. I know it quite good and have been using it for the past year.

skills.title: Xilinx ISE
skills.description: I used it to develop VHDL Programs during my Logic design and FPGA courses. I'm really not an expert in using it but I can do a few useful things like synthesizing and programming a board with it.

skills.title: Xilinx Vivado
skills.description: Refer to my Xilinx ISE description.

skills.title: WebGL
skills.description: I learned it in my Grpahics I course and have been learning about it eversince. right now I can do some basic tasks with it but I'm constantly learning to do more advanced ones with it. I've been mostly using it in form of Three.js and in web related programs.

skills.title: OpenGL
skills.description: This was the main Shader Language we were using in Computer Graphics I course, so I had to learn it in order to implement basic task. I've been also using it in parts of my thesis project. I have planned courses to further expand my knowledge in it.

skills.title: Three.JS
skills.description: Refer to my WebGL description.

skills.title: JavaScirpt (ECMA6)
skills.description: Refer to my ECMA6 description in Programming Languages section.

skills.title: React
skills.description: I learned it as a way to find the best framework for our Snappfood project. I've been working almost 24/7 with it for the past year and half and can confidently say I'm an expert in using it, extending it and also write frameworks and boilerplates with it. I know react's advanced topics and am pretty well aquainted with Redux, Thunk, Sagas, Helmet and many other react libraries.

skills.title: Vue 2
skills.description: This is a front-end framework I've been using for the past 2 years and a half and am quite an expert in it. I was a part of Nuxt development team for a while and am pretty good at developing node.js and webpack servers to do vue serverside rendering. I've done almost 5 big scale projects in Vue and Nuxt (including this site). I feel pretty much at home when developing in Vue.

skills.title: Nuxt.js
skills.description: Refer to my Vue 2 descriptions.

skills.title: Node.js
skills.description: Refer to my Node.js descriptions in programming languages sections.

skills.title: Hapi.js
skills.description: This is a good Node.js framework that we used in Fandogh, it's fast and flexible with the help to Hapi plugins, so it makes it an ideal framework to develop large-scale data-driven apps. I've been working with it for almost 2 years and although not an expert in it, I can do a lot using it.

skills.title: Laravel 5.3
skills.description: Refer to my PHP section in programming languages. I've done about 2 large-scale projects in it.

skills.title: PHP
skills.description: Refer to my PHP section in programming languages section.

skills.title: Advanced HTML 5 and CSS3
skills.description: Well I don't think these two little guys need a lot of description :D I've been working with them in one way or another for the past 4-5 years and can say I know most of the things there is to know about them. (they're so simple :D)

skills.title: MongoDB
skills.description: This was the fist NOSQL databse technology that I worked with. I used it mostly during AUT Diner project. I'm good at using it with mongoose driver in MongoDB and with the corrsponding drivers in PHP.

skills.title: 8086 Microprocessor programming
skills.description: This was the kind of programming we had to do in our microprocessor's course, I've also been programming for these chips in my final projects, my main tool of development was Atmel Studio and Arduino IDEs.

skills.title: Circuit design and analysis using Proteus
skills.description: Proteus was the main tool of visual circuit simulations in computer architecture course, I've also used it in microporcessor's project and lab and also in my final projcet sketches. I can develop complex circuits in it and can also simulate a handful of them, too.

skills.title: Layout Design using Cadence Virtuoso
skills.description: Chip layout design and implementation was the main goal of our VLSI course, so I had to use Virtuoso to make the layouts and simulate the chip circuits. I can't do more than basic layouts with it.

skills.title: Linear control system design and analysis using MATLAB
skills.description: Refer to Matlab in programming language section.

skills.title: Interface design using Arduino boards (Uno, Nano, Mega)
skills.description: Due to the simplicity to development, I used Arduino board a lot during the past years, I've especially utilized it in my thesis project and can say am pretty good in developing programs for these kinds of boards.

skills.title: Microsoft Windows
skills.description: I've been working with Windows opersting system from Windows 95 up until the very recent Windows 10, I'm also a windows insider.

skills.title: Mac OSX
skills.description: During my iOS development time I had to use this OS, I'm not an expert in using it but can find my way to things ;)

skills.title: Open SUSE
skills.description: I only worked with this OS in order to use Cadence virtuoso for a semester.

Story.text: As a teenager, I loved reading and writing stories, studying mathematics and playing some sports. So I can summarize my teenage years in these activities and of course, being a potterhead!

My passion for math, electronics and basic things I knew about programming led me to a Computer Engineering BSc. Through these four years, I tried to extend my experiences in various zones. I gained programming skills, teaching and some research experience while studying as an undergrad student.

I was chosen as a member of Student Scientific Chapter of our faculty, in which I was titled as the Head of Financial Affairs. During this year, I learned a lot about the procedure of holding different events, its requirements, managing the budget of events and the most important one, teamwork.

In my third year of studies, I came across projects about computer graphics and that was the time I knew in what field I'm gonna continue my studies. I had finally found a way to game design and development which I've always loved, but couldn't totally pursue in my country. I'm currently studying about game design and game user research and definitely enjoying it ^_^
P.S: In case of being locked up behind problems just cast alohomora!
